channel.description: Data Insights from Our World in Data

item.title: Richer countries often use much of their crops for animal feed and biofuels
item.description: By Hannah Ritchie — Richer countries tend to use less of their crops for human food, and more for animal feed and biofuels. This is what the chart shows: in several countries, less than a quarter of cereals are used for direct consumption as human food. (…)

item.title: Colonialism meant that for centuries, many territories and people were ruled from elsewhere
item.description: By Bastian Herre — Two hundred years ago, large parts of the world were ruled by a few European colonial powers, as the chart shows. (…)

item.title: Plastic recycling rates are increasing, but slowly, in many regions
item.description: By Veronika Samborska — Over the last twenty years, plastic waste recycling has considerably increased worldwide, as the chart shows. (…)

item.title: The modal age at death has been rising
item.description: By Saloni Dattani — The “modal age at death” is the most common age at which people in a population die. The modal age at death for women in Japan in 2021 was 93. In France, it was 92. (…)

item.title: Japan’s cherry trees have been blossoming earlier due to warmer spring temperatures
item.description: By Fiona Spooner — The peak flowering of cherry trees in Kyoto, Japan, has been recorded since the ninth century. Yasuyuki Aono and colleagues from the Osaka Prefecture University collated this data from historical diaries and chronicles, indicating the dates on which cherry blossom viewing parties had been held or other observations of peak blossom. (…)

item.title: Declining child mortality, fast and slow
item.description: By Max Roser — Two centuries ago, about one in three children in Sweden died before they were five years old, as you can see on the chart. (…)

item.title: A record number of objects went into space in 2023
item.description: By Edouard Mathieu — 2,664 objects were launched into space in 2023. This figure breaks the record set the previous year. (…)

item.title: Indonesia’s shift to cleaner cooking fuels has greatly improved air quality and health
item.description: By Hannah Ritchie — In 2000, less than 10% of the population in Indonesia had access to clean cooking fuels. This is now over 80%, as the chart shows. (…)

item.title: Extreme poverty in China has been almost eliminated — first in urban, then in rural regions
item.description: By Bastian Herre — In 1981, 97% of people in the Chinese countryside lived in extreme poverty. Even in cities, it was more than 70%. (…)

item.title: Solar and wind gain an edge over coal in a number of countries
item.description: By Veronika Samborska — Solar and wind have surpassed coal as a source of electricity generation in a number of countries, as the chart shows. This marks a substantial shift towards more sustainable sources of energy. (…)

item.title: Differences in life expectancy across the world are extremely large
item.description: By Esteban Ortiz-Ospina — People in richer countries tend to live much longer than those in poorer countries. (…)

item.title: Pacemakers are crucial to people with heart rhythm disorders, but their adoption varies widely
item.description: By Saloni Dattani — Pacemakers are crucial medical devices for people with heart disorders and irregular heartbeats. They provide a steady heart rhythm and help the heart pump blood effectively to the rest of the body. (…)
